metadata.title: Complete Puerto Rico POIs Database
metadata.description: Comprehensive collection of 52 points of interest across Puerto Rico
metadata.coverage: Island-wide including Vieques, Culebra, and all major municipalities
highlights: Mosquito Bay - World's brightest bioluminescent bay
Flamenco Beach - Repeatedly ranked among world's best beaches
El Yunque - Only tropical rainforest in US National Forest System
Old San Juan - Historic colonial district with blue cobblestones

pois.name: Mosquito Bay (Puerto Mosquito), Vieques
pois.description: Brightest bioluminescent bay in the world under ideal conditions; guided night paddles only.
pois.accessibility: Rough road and kayak entry; not wheelchair accessible (tours use vans/boats)
tips: Use DEET-free insect repellent; mangrove launch area is swarming with bugs
Wear quick-dry clothes and bring a towel; no changing facilities at bay
Book a guided night kayak tour in advance (only way to see the bay)
Check moon phases – new moon nights offer the brightest bioluminescence
Stay overnight on Vieques; last ferries leave before bio-bay tours end
pois.bestTimeToVisit: New moon nights for brightest glow

pois.name: Flamenco Beach, Culebra
pois.description: Turquoise, shelved bay repeatedly ranked among the world's best; amenities and camping near the sand.
pois.accessibility: Flat sandy beach with nearby lot; paths are unpaved, making wheelchair access difficult
tips: Reserve Ceiba–Culebra ferry tickets 1–2 weeks ahead (or arrive by 5 am for standby)
Pack water, snacks, and snorkel gear; limited kiosks and no shops on site
Arrive early to snag a picnic table or shaded spot before crowds
Explore west end for snorkeling by old tank; vibrant fish around reef
Bring cash for entry ($2) and parking or taxis; few ATMs on the island

pois.name: Castillo San Felipe del Morro (El Morro)
pois.description: Iconic 16th–18th century citadel guarding San Juan Bay; sprawling green lawn for kite-flying and sunsets, plus ramparts and ocean panoramas.
pois.accessibility: Historic fort with steep ramps; main plaza accessible by ramp/elevator, lower levels via stairs only
tips: Wear comfortable shoes – the fort's six levels involve steep ramps and uneven steps
Visit at opening (9 am) to beat cruise ship tour crowds and midday heat
Carry water and a hat; open courtyards get very hot (water fountains available for refills)
Try flying a kite on the lawn outside – a popular local pastime on breezy afternoons
Keep your entry receipt; one $10 ticket covers both El Morro and Castillo San Cristóbal
pois.bestTimeToVisit: Early morning (9 AM) or late afternoon for sunset

pois.name: San Juan National Historic Site
pois.description: NPS-managed complex of fortifications including Castillo San Felipe del Morro and Castillo San Cristóbal; epic coastal views, tunnels, and military history.
pois.accessibility: Steep ramps, stairs and narrow passages throughout; only key areas of forts have ramps/elevators
tips: Wear sturdy shoes – cobblestones and fortress ramps can be slippery and uneven
Use one ticket for both El Morro & San Cristóbal; save your stub for the second fort
Plan to arrive early if a cruise ship is in port, as sites get busy by late morning
Carry water and sunscreen; there is minimal shade when walking the city walls
Allow time to walk between forts (15–20 min); the free trolley service is currently suspended
pois.bestTimeToVisit: Early morning before cruise ships arrive

pois.name: Laguna Grande (Bioluminescent Bay, Fajardo)
pois.description: Year‑round bioluminescent lagoon in the Cabezas de San Juan reserve; night kayak tours through mangroves to glowing waters.
pois.accessibility: Kayak launch through narrow mangrove tunnel – not wheelchair accessible; some operators offer boat options for limited mobility
tips: Aim for a moonless night tour – darker skies mean a brighter bioluminescent glow
Combine it with an El Yunque trip; many tours offer a rainforest visit plus bio-bay in one day
Wear swimwear or quick-dry clothing; you'll get wet kayaking through mangrove channels (no changing rooms)
If traveling with young kids or mobility issues, choose an electric boat tour instead of kayaks
Bring a towel and bug spray (DEET-free); the launch area can be buggy, but chemicals harm the plankton

pois.name: La Chiva (Blue Beach), Vieques
pois.description: Long crescent of pale sand with calm waters and reefy pockets; signature south‑coast beach on Vieques.
pois.accessibility: Remote natural beach reached by dirt track; soft sand and lack of ramps make wheelchair access impractical
tips: Bring everything you'll need – no facilities or food stands here, so pack water, snacks, and sunblock
Rent a 4x4 vehicle; access is via bumpy dirt roads within the wildlife refuge
Arrive early to claim one of the few shaded spots or bring an umbrella for sun breaks
Fantastic snorkeling off this wide beach – pack snorkel gear to explore the clear waters and coral spots
Beach is often breezy with a 'wild' feel; water is usually calm, but no lifeguards so swim with caution
pois.bestTimeToVisit: Early morning for shade and calm waters

pois.name: El Yunque National Forest
pois.description: Only tropical rainforest in the U.S. National Forest System; trails to towers and cascades with frequent afternoon showers.
pois.accessibility: Mountainous terrain and slippery paths – most trails are not wheelchair-friendly (Angelito Trail is one of the few flat, accessible paths)
tips: Arrive by 7:30–8 am; entry is first-come, first-served for only 200 cars (no reservation needed now)
Bring a lightweight rain jacket and dry clothes – brief showers are daily in the rainforest
Wear shoes that can get muddy and wet (sport sandals or old sneakers with good grip)
No restaurants inside – pack water, snacks, and lunch; nearby Luquillo kiosks are great after hiking
Plan offline maps or download trail info; cell signal is poor once you're deep in the forest
pois.bestTimeToVisit: Early morning (7:30-8 AM) to secure parking

pois.name: Old San Juan
pois.description: Historic colonial district with blue cobblestones, pastel facades, and major sites like El Morro and San Cristóbal; prime base for strolling, shopping, and cafes.
pois.accessibility: Some narrow sidewalks and high curbs – parts of Old San Juan can be hard to roll through in a wheelchair, but major plazas and the forts have ramps or curb cuts
tips: Wear comfy shoes – you'll be walking on hilly cobblestone streets and steep sidewalks
Visit early morning or after 4 pm to avoid the harsh midday heat and cruise ship crowds
Carry water and sun protection; shade is limited when exploring forts and city walls
Many museums close Mon–Tue; plan around those days or check hours in advance
Wander the waterfront Paseo de la Princesa and Paseo del Morro for views, cats, and a breezy break from traffic

pois.name: La Playuela (Playa Sucia), Cabo Rojo
pois.description: Horseshoe cove below Los Morrillos lighthouse with bright water and karst cliffs; photogenic, no services.
pois.accessibility: Requires driving a rugged dirt road and a short hike over uneven ground; not accessible to wheelchairs or strollers
tips: Drive slowly on the long unpaved road to Playa Sucia – it's full of bumps, but worth every mile for the view
No facilities at this beach; bring plenty of water, food, and an umbrella or pop-up tent for shade
Climb up to Los Morrillos Lighthouse (10-min hike) for panoramic cliff views before or after your beach time
Stay in shallow areas if you're not a strong swimmer – after waist-deep the currents can pull you out quickly (no lifeguards on duty)
Visit on a weekday if possible – summer weekends get busy with local families, and parking near the trailhead fills up

pois.name: Paseo del Morro
pois.description: Seaside promenade at the base of El Morro's walls; easy flat walk with sea spray, iguanas, and camera-ready angles of the fortifications.
pois.accessibility: Wide, level gravel path along the bay – generally wheelchair accessible from the San Juan Gate side
tips: Access this scenic promenade via the San Juan Gate or from El Morro's side – it's a flat 1.5-mile trail hugging the waterfront
Go early morning or near sunset – there is no shade and midday sun can be brutal (bring a hat and water)
Keep an eye out for wildlife: you'll see cats lounging on the rocks and iguanas basking by the path
The path dead-ends at the fort's rugged coastline; turn around before dark as it's not lit at night
Stroll with sturdy shoes – though paved, the occasional uneven stones and puddles after rain mean flip-flops are less ideal

pois.name: Hotel El Convento
pois.description: Former 17th‑century Carmelite convent turned boutique hotel by the cathedral; cloistered courtyards and Old San Juan views.
pois.accessibility: Historic building retrofitted with elevators and ramps – common areas are wheelchair accessible
tips: Even if you're not staying here, pop in to admire this 17th-century former convent's architecture and lush courtyard
Enjoy the daily complimentary wine & cheese hour if you are a guest – a lovely tradition on the terrace at sundown
Dress in smart casual attire especially in the evenings; the hotel maintains an elegant atmosphere
Parking in Old San Juan is tricky – consider a taxi or nearby parking garage, then walk to the hotel
Rooms are boutique-style with colonial decor – even non-guests can visit the lobby and art gallery
pois.bestTimeToVisit: Anytime for lobby visit; sunset for wine hour
pois.estimatedDuration: 1 hour for visit, stay for lodging

pois.name: Cayo Icacos
pois.description: Uninhabited islet off Fajardo with clear water and reefs; popular boat/snorkel day trip.
pois.accessibility: Requires boarding a boat and sometimes transferring to a dinghy – not recommended for serious mobility limitations
tips: Book a catamaran or water taxi in advance – Icacos is only reachable by boat, and tours fill up fast
Mornings are best: seas are typically calmer and you'll have more of the island to yourself
There are zero facilities on this uninhabited cay – bring reef-safe sunscreen, a hat, and beach essentials
Snorkel the reef on the east side for colorful fish and coral; ask guides about current strength
Keep the island pristine – carry out all your trash with tour crews

pois.name: Punta Borinquen Light (Aguadilla)
pois.description: Historic lighthouse set on cliffs above Aguadilla and the former Ramey Air Force Base; dramatic coastal vistas.
pois.accessibility: Variable depending on access route

pois.name: Mar Chiquita (Manatí)
pois.description: Pocket beach in a round cove protected by limestone rock walls; calm on low swell, dramatic in winter surf.
pois.accessibility: Natural beach with variable access

pois.name: Condado Vanderbilt Hotel
pois.description: 1919 grande dame hotel on Ashford Avenue; restored classic with oceanfront terraces and upscale dining.
pois.accessibility: Modern accessibility features
pois.estimatedDuration: Stay for lodging or visit for dining

pois.name: Yokahú Tower (El Yunque)
pois.description: 1963 observation tower with sweeping Luquillo range and coast views; short climb from the parking area.
pois.accessibility: Requires climbing stairs to top

pois.name: Domes Beach (Playa Domes), Rincón
pois.description: Powerful winter surf near the decommissioned BONUS reactor and Punta Higuero Lighthouse; strong currents, experienced swimmers only.
pois.accessibility: Beach access from parking area
pois.bestTimeToVisit: Winter for surf, summer for calmer conditions

pois.name: Piñones State Forest
pois.description: Mangrove coast with bike path, rustic kiosks, and local fritura stands; excellent for a food-and-beach loop outside San Juan.
pois.accessibility: Bike path is relatively flat and accessible

pois.name: Cueva del Indio (Arecibo)
pois.description: Sea cave and cliff arches with Taíno petroglyphs and blowholes; spectacular coastal geology.
pois.accessibility: Requires hiking over uneven terrain

pois.name: Casa Bacardí (Cathedral of Rum), Cataño
pois.description: Visitor center and historic distillery complex of Bacardí across the bay from Old San Juan; cocktail classes and tastings.
pois.accessibility: Tour facilities are accessible

pois.name: La Placita de Santurce
pois.description: Daytime produce market that flips to nightlife hub after dark; bars, music, and restaurants radiate from the historic plaza.
pois.accessibility: Plaza is generally accessible
pois.bestTimeToVisit: Evening for nightlife, morning for market

pois.name: Maria's Beach, Rincón
pois.description: Classic Rincón break with consistent sets; beach bars and whale watching in season.
pois.accessibility: Beach access from parking
pois.bestTimeToVisit: Winter for surf and whale watching

pois.name: Castillo San Cristóbal
pois.description: Largest Spanish fortification in the Americas. Underground tunnels, moats, and city views. Often cited as the better interior fort experience vs El Morro.
pois.accessibility: Ramps and stairs; uneven surfaces
tips: Use the same NPS ticket as El Morro
Explore the tunnels and Garita del Diablo overlook
Less shade than you think; hydrate

pois.name: Gozalandia Waterfalls (San Sebastián)
pois.description: Two-tiered falls with deep pools and cliff-jump spots. Popular on weekends and repeatedly suggested for west-side itineraries.
pois.accessibility: Steep paths; not wheelchair accessible
tips: Small entry/parking fee
Slippery rocks; water shoes recommended
Go early to avoid crowds

pois.name: Crash Boat Beach (Aguadilla)
pois.description: Lively west-coast beach with pier remnants, clear days for snorkeling, food kiosks. Frequently mentioned, especially at sunset.
pois.accessibility: Beach access from parking; sandy entry
tips: Parking fills by late morning, especially weekends
Water clarity varies with swell
Arrive early to avoid crowds

pois.name: Condado (Santurce)
pois.description: High-energy beachfront district with resorts, shopping, and dining along Ashford Avenue; good base for walkers and beach-seekers.
pois.accessibility: Modern area with good accessibility
pois.estimatedDuration: Stay for lodging or day visit

pois.name: Isla Verde
pois.description: Resort and residential strip east of Condado with a broad sandy beach and quick airport access.
pois.accessibility: Modern resort area with good accessibility
pois.estimatedDuration: Stay for lodging or day visit

pois.name: Cayey (municipality)
pois.description: Cooler mountain town that anchors the Guavate lechón route and access to Carite forest and reservoirs.
pois.accessibility: Variable by specific location

pois.name: Jayuya
pois.description: Mountain town in central Puerto Rico known for coffee, cooler temperatures, and indigenous Taíno culture.
pois.accessibility: Variable by specific location

pois.name: Coabey
pois.description: Rural community in the mountains of Jayuya with traditional Puerto Rican culture.
pois.accessibility: Rural mountain area

San Juan Metro.description: Urban area including Old San Juan, Condado, Isla Verde, and Santurce

Northeast.description: El Yunque rainforest, bioluminescent bay, and island excursions
Northeast.accessibility: Variable, many natural areas not accessible

Vieques.description: Former Navy island with pristine beaches and bio bay

Culebra.accessibility: Very limited, requires ferry or flight

West Coast.description: Surf beaches, sunsets, and whale watching in winter

Southwest.description: Remote beaches, lighthouse, and dramatic cliffs

Central Mountains.description: Coffee country, cooler temperatures, cultural sites

transportation.car_rental: Recommended for exploring beyond San Juan metro
transportation.ferry_service: Ceiba to Vieques/Culebra - book in advance
